The development of new application scenarios for the red mud, a huge by-product from the aluminum manufacture, has become urgent because of the increasingly stringent demands of environmental protection. Herein, a very simple and sustainable approach to the design of a synergistic catalytic system for the direct oxidative cross-coupling of alcohols and amines to (un)symmetric imines by physically mixing MnO x and red mud is presented. With the catalysis of active red mud, the synthesis of imines over MnO x can achieve an excellent (>98%) yield at 60 °C, air as oxidant for 8 h Without this catalysis, the imine yield reaches only 25%. The red mud clearly assists the reaction, resulting in a 4 ∼ 10-folds higher increase over reactions using only MnO x . From detailed experiments and characterizations, the synergistic effects of the extraordinary performance of this catalytic system were confirmed to be a combination of the reactivity of MnO x in the oxidation of alcohols and the enhancement by the active red mud in the condensation of aldehydes and amines. This work demonstrates a facile strategy for revival of the hazardous red mud. It could turn “waste” into wealth and greatly promote the catalytic applications of red mud. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MnO x Red mud Synergistic catalysis Imine synthesis Cross-coupling Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the rapid utilization of natural resources, the industrial hazardous waste output increases over years, and it is a material which is freely available to be used as catalysts or supports [1–6]. Among industrial wastes, red mud (RM) from the aluminum industry, with main components such as Fe2O3, Al2O3, SiO2, Na2O, CaO and TiO2 etc., is produced in the highest amounts (1.5 ∼ 2.5 tons RM per 1 ton alumina) and has the lowest reutilization rate (< 10%) [7–9]. Most of the RM is disposed in landfills or dams without any pretreatment [10,11], but the high alkalinity and harmful metals in RM can cause drastic destroy to the health of all living things and environment problems. Thus, there is an urgent need for clean, safe and valuable technologies for the valorization of RM [12]. In the past decades, a great deal of effort has been made to the utilize RM as catalysts in different transformations, including Fe-based catalysis (hydrogenation, oxidation, Fenton-like process), base catalysis (catalytic cracking, catalytic pyrolysis) or as catalyst supports [1,13–21]. Such achievements have the potential to resolve the RM-based catalyst problems. Nitrogen-containing organic compounds are widely applications in many aspects of our daily life [22–27]. Imines, as a class of important nitrogen-containing compounds, have been attracted much concerns with their key roles in synthesis of various dyes, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals and biologically active compounds as well as an intermediates in the production of secondary amines [28–34]. Owing to their importance, versatile methods for imine synthesis have been developed, including condensation of aldehydes and amines, oxidative dehydrogenation of secondary amines, oxidative coupling of primary alkylamine and the direct cross-coupling of alcohol and primary amines [35–38]. Of all the above strategies, direct cross-coupling of alcohols and amines is highly-focused because the unsymmetric imines are readily formed from alcohols and amines, water is the only by-product of the reaction and air can be used as a gratis oxidant. These advantages promise that the transformation should be environmentally benign [30,39–43]. This reaction is a representative tandem process, which includes an oxidation process with redox catalysts and a condensation process with acidic catalysts (Scheme 1 ). Thus, to acquire considerable selectivity and yield of the imine in this transformation, three strategies have received attention: (1) loading more catalysts [44,45]; (2) raising the reaction temperature or prolonging the reaction time [45,46]; and (3) designing an dual-sites catalysts with redox and acid sites [42]. MnO x is a cheap and effective catalyst for various catalytic oxidation reactions [47–49]. Selecting self-coupling of amines or cross-coupling of alcohols and amines to imines as examples, unmodified manganese oxide as a catalyst has unsatisfactory catalytic activity, leading to operate the reaction at relatively harsh conditions such as high catalysis loadings and reaction temperatures, long reaction times, oxidants other than air and complicated control of the morphology or crystal structure of the MnO2 [50,51]. To overcome these difficulties and develop high performance Mn-based catalysts, different strategies such as impregnation of MnO x into materials with large specific surface areas or with different functionalities, such as MnO x /TiO2@SBA-15 [52], MnO x /HAP [53], MnO2/GO [54], MnO2/CeO2 [55], metal-doped MnO2 (Cs/MnO x [56,57], Co/MnO2 [45], Ce/MnO2 [58]), Mn-based composite oxides (MnCo2O4 [44], Fe5Mn5-100 [59]) and solid solution (Mn1Zr x O y ) [60,61] have been studied. Despite numerous reports highlighting the Mn-based catalysts for the imine synthesis, the search for milder, cheaper and more scalable adjustment of the Mn-based catalysts is still in high demand. Herein, a simple and cheap strategy of combining MnO x as a redox catalyst and the treated RM as Lewis acidic catalyst for the tandem oxidative cross-coupling of alcohols and amines is developed. The abundant Lewis acidic sites in RM can significantly speed-up the benzaldehyde-aniline condensation process, even at low concentrations of benzaldehyde. Consequently, the efficiency of the entire reaction can be improved. These inspiring results not only exhibit a sustainable approach to turn hazardous RM into valuable catalytic materials but also provide a promising direction to solve the issues associated with pollution by RM. 2 Experimental 2.1 RM treatment Three different batches of RM samples were collected from Zibo city, Shandong Provinces, China. RM was treated by nitric acid digestion and ammonium hydroxide reprecipitation procedure adopted from our previous literature without any change [9]. The dried precipitate was treated at 400 °C in a muffle oven for 3 h, termed active RM (ARM). Similarly, another two red muds were treated by same procedure and denote as ARM-2, ARM-3. 2.2 Preparation of MnO x MnO x was prepared by prepared by calcination of MnCO3 at 300–600 °C in muffle oven for 3 h with the temperature increasing at 5 °C·min−1. Accordingly, the samples were denoted as MnO x -T (T = 300, 400, 500, 600). 2.3 General procedure for the oxidative cross-coupling reaction ARM (10 mg), MnO x -400 (10 mg), benzyl alcohol (0.5 mmol, ∼52 μL), aniline (1.2 equiv., ∼55 μL) and toluene (2 mL) were mixed in a 10 mL Shrek tube containing a stir bar, then connected with an air balloon at 60 °C for 8 h. After time's up, the reaction liquid was analyzed by GC with dodecane as internal standard and GC-MS (Supporting Information, Figs. S1–S3). 2.4 Condensation of benzaldehyde with amines to imines ARM (10 mg), benzaldehyde (0.5 mmol, ∼51 μL), aniline (0.5 mmol, ∼46 μL) and toluene (2 mL) were mixed in a 10 mL Shrek tube containing a stir bar, then connected with an air balloon at 60 °C for 8 h. The reaction operation at rt. for 30 min. After time's up, the reaction liquid was analyzed by GC with dodecane as internal standard and GC-MS. 2.5 Characterization of catalysts X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer, X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, N2 adsorption/desorption, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and Pyridine-IR were applied to characterize the physico-chemical property of the red mud, active red mud and MnO x . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the red mud and MnO x XRF was used to analysis the chemical composition of the RM and ARM. As shown in Table 1 , after the acid digestion and the alkali reprecipitation procedure, most of Na2O was removed and the final composition of the ARM was Fe2O3 (52.6%), Al2O3 (20.7%), SiO2 (17.2%), Na2O (0.3%), TiO2 (7.3%) and CaO (0.4%). XPS was also applied to analysis the different between RM and ARM, the main elements and valence state of RM and ARM were nearly unchanged, except sodium (Fig. S4). After the treatment, typical XRD peaks of the hematite (Fe2O3), quartz (SiO2), rutile (TiO2) and corundum (Al2O3) were still present in the ARM. Meanwhile, the characteristic peaks of the cancrinite (Na6CaAl6Si6(CO3)O24·2H2O), gibbsite (Al(OH)3), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), goethite (FeOOH), diaspore (AlO(OH)), sodium hydroxide (NaOH) disappeared [14,62–64]. The surface area and pore volume were confirmed by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements. The RM has Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 25.5 m2·g−1 and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore volume of 0.08 cm3·g−1. The ARM showed an improvement of both BET surface area and BJH pore volume to 53.5 m2·g−1 and 0.12 cm3·g−1, respectively (Fig. 1 b). SEM images confirmed that smaller particles in nanoscale formed after the treatment (Fig. 1c and d), which might be the reason for the enlargement of the surface area and pore volume. A high surface area and pore volume may provide more active sites in catalytic reactions. XRD was employed for the structural transformation of the MnO x based samples. The representative XRD diffraction peaks of MnCO3 disappeared after calcination at 300 °C, and no crystallinity was seen in the MnO x -300 that was formed. After treatment at 400 °C, a small peak appeared at 2θ = 37o, which was attributed to the formation of crystalline MnO2. Various sharp peaks appeared in the XRD patterns of MnO x -500, which were assigned to the formed β-MnO2 structure [50,65]. After treatment at 600 °C, representative diffraction peaks of Mn2O3 were detected [66,67] (Fig. 2 a). The morphology of the as-prepared MnO x based materials were investigated by SEM (Figs. 2b and S5,6). After the MnCO3 was calcinated to form MnO x , a peach-like structure was clearly observed with particles ∼1 μm diameter. The surface elemental compositions and transformation was also analyzed by XPS. Fig. 2c demonstrates the C1s core-level photoelectron spectra of MnCO3 and the MnOx samples. The C1s peaks centered at 289.5 and 284.8 eV correspond to the photoelectron spectra of carbonate (CO3 2−) and adventitious carbon, respectively. After calcination, the characteristic band of CO3 2− was significantly diminished, indicating that the MnCO3 had decomposed during the calcination process [67]. The C1s results were in accord with and XRD data. The O1s peaks centered at 533.6, 531.9, 531.6 and 529.6 eV correspond to the characteristic bands of the hydroxyl group, surface adsorbed oxygen, oxygen in CO3 2− and lattice oxygen, respectively (Fig. 2d). Calcination at 400 °C caused remarkable transformations in the O1s spectra. A new fraction appeared in the O1s band at ∼531.9 eV, and was associated with the surface adsorbed oxygen [67–71]. However, the portions of the surface adsorbed oxygen in MnO x decreased with further treating MnCO3 at 500 and 600 °C. The highest concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen was obtained with MnO x -400, which demonstrated that the amorphous structures provided more sites for the oxygen adsorption. This characteristic might be suitable for the catalysis in the selective oxidation reaction. 3.2 MnO x /ARM synergistic catalysts The direct oxidative cross-coupling of benzyl alcohol and aniline forming an imine, N-benzylideneaniline, was selected as a model reaction to screen the catalytic activity of different MnO x species in RM and ARM and their mixture at 60 °C. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the amorphous MnO x -300 and MnO x -400 showed better activities than others, delivering yields of 25 ∼ 27% in this oxidative cross-coupling reaction with poor selectivity. The abundant of surface oxygen species in the amorphous MnO x was the main reason for the better performance. The MnCO3 and commercial MnO2 did not show any obvious catalytic effect under the same condition, because they appear to lack the ability to activate the oxygen. Loading more catalysts did improve the yield of imines, but the reaction was still uneconomical (Fig. S7). RM and ARM were both nearly inactive in the reaction (Fig. 3a), demonstrating no oxidative activity with the reaction. Surprisingly, an inspiring enhancement for the Mn-based samples was observed, especially for those with MnO x (Fig. 3b). The results demonstrated a synergistic effect in this reaction between the MnO x and the ARM. The physical mixture of original RM and MnO x also showed signs of promoting the reaction, but the synergistic effect was obviously lower when compared to the reaction with ARM. When the MnO x -400 and ARM was used as a combined catalytic system, the yield of N-benzylideneaniline was reached 98%. As Fig. S8 shows, the different calcination temperature of the ARM has less affected to the catalytic activity. In addition, we further use another two red muds with different batches and ingredients, obvious synergistic effects are also existed between active red mud and MnO x -400 (Tables S1 and S2). These results suggest that the existence of some differences on the content and the composition of the red mud has less affected to the catalytic activity. Fe2O3, Al2O3, SiO2, Na2O and TiO2 are the five major constituents in our red mud sample. We then tested individual oxides impact on the oxidative cross-coupling of alcohol and amines. Firstly, in the ARM sample, more than 99.9% of Na2O was removed through medication process. Catalytic results have shown that the ARM can greatly promoting the yield of imines and therefore, the possibility of the Na2O catalyzed this reaction was excluded (Fig. 3b). Then, Fe2O3, Al2O3, SiO2, and TiO2 were also tested based on their ratio in ARM and found to be effective up to a point, but the efficiency gap between individual oxide and ARM was obvious (Fig. S9). These results indicate that ARM is the most effective promoter for the imine synthesis among the single components. Then, the ARM loadings in these transformations with a range of 0 ∼ 10 mg were explored. The transformation of benzyl alcohol and the yield of imine increased immediately with 1 mg of ARM in the reaction (Fig. 4 a and b). Further increases in the amount of ARM that was used improved the reaction efficiency. To show a comparative aspect, a control experiments were runs over MnO x -400 catalysts for 2 or 3 h and over MnO x -400 catalysts for 2 h then 10 mg ARM added to the mixture for another 1 h (Fig. 4c and d). For the MnO x -400 catalyst, both the conversion and yield were increased by extending the reaction time, but the activity and selectivity were still unsatisfactory. Surprisingly, once the ARM was added into the reaction system for another 1 h, the selectivity of imine was significantly increased to 96%, and the conversion reached 51%. Based on all these results, it was concluded that the ARM is important for this transformation. Ma et al. reported that amorphous Fe2O3, the main component of ARM, improving the active oxygen transfer in Mn3O4, and improved the catalytic activity of Mn based catalysts [59]. Previous results indicated that abundant Lewis acid sites exist in red mud-based materials and Lewis acid was a catalyst for the condensation of amines with aldehydes to imines [72–74]. Thus, there are two possible roles for ARM in the catalytic process: it may behave as an oxygen mediator or a Lewis acid catalyst. 3.3 Insight into the mechanism of the MnO x /ARM synergistic catalysts According to a previous report, oxidative cross-coupling of alcohol and amine to imines proceeds in two steps: 1. selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde, 2. imine generation from benzaldehyde and amines [74]. Thus, to clarify the contribution from ARM, the oxidation part and condensation part of this cascade process were examined separately. Benzyl alcohol oxidation over MnO x -400 or MnO x -400/ARM catalyst are performed, MnO x -400 clearly catalyzed the reaction, while ARM showed no enhancement of the oxidation process (Fig. 5 a). Therefore, we confirmed that ARM was not an oxygen mediator in the mechanism. Fig. 5b shows the condensation results of benzaldehyde and aniline with different catalytic systems. A low concentration of benzaldehyde was felt to be suitable and was used because the initial concentration of benzaldehyde was relatively low during the reaction. With 0.05 M of benzaldehyde for example, ARM showed better performance than MnO x in the condensation step. With ARM, the complete conversion of benzaldehyde only in 2 h at rt., and the 100% conversion of benzaldehyde over the MnO x -400 was required tripling times (6 h). Compared with the result of the reaction with no catalyst, the MnO x obviously had no catalytic activity in this step. At a concentration of 0.01 M, the ARM provided the 100% conversion in 25 min, and under the same conditions, only 10% conversion of benzaldehyde took place in the absence of catalysts (Fig. 5c). Therefore, it can be considered that the Lewis acid sites in ARM greatly accelerate the condensation step even in the low concentration range, The benzaldehyde generated in the oxidation step is consumed quickly, and consequently the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde can also be accelerated based on the chemical equilibria. To proof of the catalytic results, NH3-TPD and pyridine-IR are chosen to assess the acidity in the RM and ARM. Firstly, the acidic sites in the RM and the ARM are identified by NH3-TPD. As shown in Fig. 6 a, both samples showed two NH3 desorption peaks at 146 and 512 °C, which can be ascribed to weak and strong acidic sites, respectively. Apparently, the ARM possesses many more acidic sites than the RM. Then, the nature of Brønsted and Lewis acids in the two samples were also identified by the pyridine-IR analyzes [75]. The ARM manifested abundant Lewis acid sites, as shown by the appearance of bands at 1445, 1490 and 1594 cm−1 (Fig. 6b). In the RM sample, however, the pyridine-IR results did not contain large amounts of Lewis or Brønsted acid sites, which might be caused by the blocking effect of the abundant alkaline ions [76–79]. This could also explain why the RM is not a good catalyst in this reaction. The pyridine-IR analysis also showed the weak nature of the Lewis acid in MnO x -400 (Fig. S10), which demonstrates the necessity of MnO x /ARM synergistic catalysis in this transformation [80,81]. Based on these results, a proposed reaction mechanism over MnO x /ARM synergistic catalytic system was developed and is displayed in Scheme 2 , where MnO x catalyzes the oxidation step and the ARM enhances the condensation step. 3.4 Substrate scope and stability of ARM catalysts To demonstrate the potential and widespread applicability of the synergistic catalysis, arylamines with diversity functional groups were investigated (Scheme 3 ). The synergistic catalytic system is efficient with various substituted arylamines, including 4-methyl, ethyl, isopropyl, tert-butyl, methoxy, 4-isopropoxy, fluoro, chloro, bromo, iodo and trifluoro, giving the imines in good to excellent yields. Aniline was used as the substrate to observe the general nature of benzyl alcohol derivatives. Methyl- and methoxy-substituted benzyl alcohols were reacted and produced the desired imines in good yield; chloro- and bromo-functionalized benzyl alcohol were also reacted and formed imines in good yields. The excellent activity of ARM in the condensation process was further highlighted by the synthesis of imines from aldehydes and amines. In all cases, the desired imines were obtained in excellent yields (80 ∼ 99%) at rt in 30 min (Scheme 4 ). These broad substrate scopes results demonstrated the universality of the MnO x /ARM atalytic system in a divergent preparation of imines from the reaction of alcohols or aldehydes with amines. To proof the stability of ARM catalysts in the condensation process, a recycling experiment was carried out. The experiments demonstrated that the activity of ARM decreased only slightly from the first measurement even after 7 cycles (Fig. 7 ). To further illustrate the simple preparation and excellent activity of the MnO x -400/ARM catalytic system, the comparison of catalytic results of various reported Mn-based catalysts are shown in Table 2 . The fabrication of MnO x /ARM is quite simple and exhibits commensurable performance when compared to the reported excellent Mn-based catalysts, such as Fe5Mn5-100 and Mn1Zr0.5Oy. This present study describes the first example of simple MnO x /ARM as a synergistic catalyst in the oxidative cross-coupling of alcohol and amine. 4 Conclusion We have demonstrated an oxidative cross-coupling of alcohols and amines via a simple mixing MnO x /ARM catalysts which produces various imines under mild conditions. MnO x was proved to be responsible only for the selective alcohol oxidation to aldehydes and ARM enhanced the condensation of aldehyde and amines to give the desired products. The unprecedented MnO x /ARM synergistic catalysis in our study not only provides a highly effective approach for the preparation of imines, but also greatly promotes the potential transformation of the key hazardous industrial wastes into valuable materials. Further experiments are being explored to diversify the use of the RM in catalysis based on the core of sustainable development and environmental economy. coredata.dc:description: The development of new application scenarios for the red mud, a huge by-product from the aluminum manufacture, has become urgent because of the increasingly stringent demands of environmental protection. Herein, a very simple and sustainable approach to the design of a synergistic catalytic system for the direct oxidative cross-coupling of alcohols and amines to (un)symmetric imines by physically mixing MnO x and red mud is presented. With the catalysis of active red mud, the synthesis of imines over MnO x can achieve an excellent (>98%) yield at 60 °C, air as oxidant for 8 h Without this catalysis, the imine yield reaches only 25%. The red mud clearly assists the reaction, resulting in a 4 ∼ 10-folds higher increase over reactions using only MnO x . From detailed experiments and characterizations, the synergistic effects of the extraordinary performance of this catalytic system were confirmed to be a combination of the reactivity of MnO x in the oxidation of alcohols and the enhancement by the active red mud in the condensation of aldehydes and amines. This work demonstrates a facile strategy for revival of the hazardous red mud. It could turn “waste” into wealth and greatly promote the catalytic applications of red mud.
coredata.dc:title: Red mud-mediated cross-coupling of alcohols and amines to imines over MnO x catalysts
